comments.author: Andrea Santamaria Irusta
comments.msg: Hola chicos, Tenemos que entregar la Gran Fiesta en inglÃÂ©s. Me han pasado los tecnhical specifications, para que lo tengÃÂ¡is en cuenta ya que piden specificaciones concretas.Respecto al formato, entre lo que he leÃÂ­do no me queda claro el formato que piden para archivos en SD, por favor confirmadme si lo dicen o debo preguntar. Gracias, AndreAExhibit Ã¢ÂÂBÃ¢ÂÂ - BVI Technical Specifications All materials delivered to BVI for Television are to conform to the following technical and delivery specifications. 1. TECHNICAL SPECIFICATIONS1.1 VIDEO Video LevelsThe video level must not exceed 700mV (with 3% tolerance) for the luminance channel and + 350 mV for the color difference channels.  No excursions below black level can be tolerated in the luminance channel (i.e., never below 0mV). Horizontal Signal FilteringThese filters should satisfy the following characteristics:Ã¢ÂÂ¢	The 10% to 90% rise time period should lie between 300 ns and 350 ns.Ã¢ÂÂ¢	No over or undershoot should be produced on a non-bandlimited step response input.Vertical Signal FilteringThe measuring equipment should indicate that an "Out-of-Gamut" error has occurred only when the error occupies an integrated area of the active screen exceeding 1%.Aspect Ratio & Safe AreasAll Programs are to be shot and mastered with the aspect ratio of 16x9, otherwise expressed as 1:78:1 in full Frame without any letterboxing. Additionally, all 16x9 Programs must be center-cut extractable to 4x3 aspect ratio, without the need for pan and scan or repositioning of shots.  All text, including main titles and end credits must fall within the 4x3 title-safe area.1.1.1 High Definition (HD) VideoPrograms in HD shall be in the format of 1080 PsF (progressive-segmented frame) with 4:2:2 color sub-sampling ratio. It must have a resolution of 1920 pixels (horizontal) by 1080 pixels (vertical).  Gamut shall comply with the required ITU BT.709 colour space. All footage shot with an HD video camera must be captured at a full resolution of 1080 lines, at 25fps (or 30fps as applicable).  All footage shot on film must be transferred in 1080 line resolution, at 25fps (or 30fps as applicable). Master HD Programs must comply with technical standards for HD production as detailed in the following documents:Ã¢ÂÂ¢	ITU-R BT.709-5 Part 2 Ã¢ÂÂParameter values for the HDTV standards for production and international programme exchangeÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ¢	EBU Tech 3299 (S2 and S3) Ã¢ÂÂHigh Definition (HD) Image Formats for Television ProductionÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ¢	SMPTE S274-2008 Ã¢ÂÂTelevision - 1920 x 1080 Image Sample Structure, Digital Representation and Digital Timing Reference Sequences for Multiple Picture RatesÃ¢ÂÂ (Revision of SMPTE 274M-2005)1.2 AUDIOThe audio supplied with the material shall be without any pre-emphasis or noise reduction scheme applied to it. There also should not be any visible lip-sync or perceptible errors in the audio.Audio LevelsAlignment level of digital audio should be set 18dB below the maximum possible coding level of the digital system at -18dBFS (or -20dBFS as applicable). Digital audio peaks in Programs should not be allowed to exceed 9 dB above the alignment level when measured by a quasi-peak programme meter (PPM). Average peak shall be -12 to -10 dB and up to -6 dB catering to occasional background special efx like explosions, footsteps, traffic etc.BVI has adopted EBUÃ¢ÂÂs recommendation for audio loudness normalisation & permitted maximum level, formally known as EBU R128-2011. This recommendation states that the Programme Loudness Level shall be normalised to a Target Level of -23.0 LUFS. The permitted deviation from the Target Level shall generally not exceed ÃÂ±1.0 LU. The following conditions also help to define the recommendation:(i)	That the audio signal shall generally be measured in its entirety, without emphasis on specific elements such as voice, music or sound effects;(ii)	That the measurement shall be made with a loudness meter compliant with both ITU-R BS.1770 and EBU Tech Doc 3341(iii)	That this measurement shall include a gating method as specified in ITU-R BS.1770 (summarized in EBU Technical Document 3341)(iv)	That Loudness Range shall be measured with a meter compliant with EBU Tech Doc 3342(v)	That the Maximum Permitted True Peak Level of a programme during production shall be -1 dBTP (dB True Peak), measured with a meter compliant with both ITU-R BS.1770 and EBU Tech Doc 3341.(vi)	The recommendation applies to Stereo, LT/RT and 5.1 mixes.Audio Sampling RateBVI will only accept Programs with audio acquired, duplicated, stored on any media or post produced at 48kHz.Audio Compression and LimitingUse of audio compression or limiting to achieve the required audio levels or prevent peak distortion is permitted only if such use does not induce audible defects.  Over-compressed audio or Ã¢ÂÂclippedÃ¢ÂÂ audio will not be accepted.All audio signals in Programs must comply with technical standards for production as detailed in the following documents:Ã¢ÂÂ¢	ITU-R BS.1596 Ã¢ÂÂGuide to ITU-R Recommendations for broadcast sound productionÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ¢	EBU Technical Recommendation R68-2000 Ã¢ÂÂAlignment level in digital audio production equipment and in digital audio recordersÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ¢	ITU-R BS.646-1 Ã¢ÂÂSource encoding for digital sound signals in broadcasting studiosÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ¢	Dolby 5.1 Channel Production GuidelinesÃ¢ÂÂ¢	EBU Technical Recommendation R128-2011 Ã¢ÂÂLoudness normalisation and permitted maximum level of audio signalsÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ¢	EBU Tech Doc 3341 Ã¢ÂÂLoudness Metering: Ã¢ÂÂEBU ModeÃ¢ÂÂ metering to supplement loudness normalisation in accordance with EBU R 128Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ¢	EBU Tech Doc 3342 Ã¢ÂÂLoudness Range: A measure to supplement loudness normalisation in accordance with EBU R 128Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ¢	ITU-R BS.1770-3 Ã¢ÂÂAlgorithms to measure audio programme loudness and true-peak audio levelÃ¢ÂÂ 1.2.1 Audio for Stereo Audio MixesThe audio supplied with Programs shall be in stereo, where available, with no Dolby encoding.  Line Up ToneAudio line up signals must be set to -18dBFS (or -20dBFS as applicable). Line-up tone should be broken 1/4 second every 3 seconds to identify left channel.Mono CompatibilityAll stereo mixes shall be fully mono compatible.  Any sonic elements audible in stereo mixes shall also be audible when collapsed into a mono signal.An audio mix of both channels shall reproduce a correct mono signal.  The overall dynamic range of Programs shall not exceed 30dB.Any deviation from the above specifications will not be accepted unless pre-approved by BVI.Ã¢ÂÂ2. DELIVERY SPECIFICATIONSLicensor shall use its best efforts to supply the best quality copy available.  Consideration should be given to the number of generations, original production format, etc. to comply with this requirement.Programs should be delivered in a continuous form.  If the Programs originally contained commercial break slots, etc., then all bumpers should be removed from the program and commercial blacks must be edited to approximately 1 second in length (without eliminating any audio).2.1 GENERAL MASTERING FORMATHead Format - All Programs shall have the following head format:Timecode	Events00:58:00:00	Black 00:58:30:00	EBU reference bars (100/0100/0) and line-up tone 1khz tone @ -18dBFS (or -20dBFS as applicable)00:59:30:00	Black00:59:50:00	Slate 00:59:57:00	Black 01:00:00:00	Start of Program	End Credits	Logo 	End of Program (EOP)EOP 	Black for 2 minutesEOP + 2 mins		Textless Main Title	Textless background for episodic titles (Open & Close)	Any and all textless for texted material within the program	Textless end title2.1.1 Breaks When Programs are broken into segments, all breaks must be 12 frames in duration (1/2 second). The duration of a break will be defined as follows:  The area of black, from the point when both video and audio cease to be present, to the point when either video or audio (whichever comes first) becomes present again.For example, if a break has 24 frames of video black between segments, but the outgoing segment has 12 frames of audio ring-out trailing into the black, then the duration of the break is 12 frames since only 12 of the 24 black frames are devoid of both video and audio.2.1.2 Slates & Labelling Programs shall contain the following information on labels (for tapes) and slates:Ã¢ÂÂ¢	Full titleÃ¢ÂÂ¢	Episode number (if applicable)Ã¢ÂÂ¢	Episode titleÃ¢ÂÂ¢	Production numberÃ¢ÂÂ¢	Exact program running time (in minutes and seconds)Ã¢ÂÂ¢	Date material was produced Ã¢ÂÂ¢	Name of mastering vendor Ã¢ÂÂ¢	Specific technical audio information, including complete breakdown of the contents of each channelÃ¢ÂÂ¢	Indication of textless backgrounds and bumpers 120 seconds after end of programÃ¢ÂÂ¢	Time code typeÃ¢ÂÂ¢	Production company2.1.3 Textless BackgroundsLicensor shall supply completely textless backgrounds (absolutely no text) recorded 120 seconds after end of each Program.  These textless backgrounds shall be supplied for any shots within the show which contain text, including but not limited to main titles, end titles, episodic titles, subtitled scenes, and any explanatory titles (such as dates, locales, character names, closed captioned and stereo buys, etc.). Textless backgrounds are also required for any shots containing phone numbers that do not adhere to the clearance requirements stated in the Section 2.2.4 Ã¢ÂÂTelephone Numbers and License PlatesÃ¢ÂÂ.  This includes both practical elements, such as video screens, props, set dressing, etc, as well as electronically generated numbers.  The textless background section shall be preceded by a video slate specifying the textless materials to follow.  All textless material shall be M.O.S. on all audio tracks.   Said textless backgrounds shall be comprised of each entire shot (Ã¢ÂÂhard cut to hard cutÃ¢ÂÂ, including a 2-frame handle on the head and tail of the shot), which corresponds to a shot containing text.  Textless backgrounds-shall contain any and all photographically or electronically generated effects present in the video master, including but not limited to fades, dissolves, wipes, blow-ups, hold-frames, and multiple exposures.  There must be at least 7 frames of black in between each textless shot/sequence.  Bumpers shall be included in this textless section in both texted and textless forms, and shall contain corresponding audio. Channels 1 and 2 shall contain composite stereo English audio (generic audio, no network or station IDÃ¢ÂÂs). Channels 3 and 4 shall contain stereo music and effects (minus voice-over and vocals).When Textless is required:The general rule is any shots containing Ã¢ÂÂelectronically generatedÃ¢ÂÂ text or Ã¢ÂÂphoto-chemically generatedÃ¢ÂÂ text must have matching textless material.  Such text is applied to the program after the scene has been shot.  With animated product, such text is often created as part of the animation, but made to appear as generated text.i.	Credits:The most common use of this type of applied text is main titles and end credits.  These will always require textless backgrounds unless the Original text is over black.  Other common forms of applied text requiring textless backgrounds are that of episodic title cards and episodic titles.    ii.	Text Within Program:Text that is generated and/or superimposed over picture to inform the viewer of dates and locations require textless backgrounds.  Examples:  Ã¢ÂÂLondon Ã¢ÂÂ 1812Ã¢ÂÂ and Ã¢ÂÂfive hours later.Ã¢ÂÂ  Another example of text within program is Ã¢ÂÂTo be continuedÃ¢ÂÂ¦Ã¢ÂÂWhen Textless is not required:i.	Set Pieces:Original text viewable on objects and scenery (set pieces) which are then shot by the camera is not required to have matching textless backgrounds.  Examples of this would be text on signs, posters, store fronts, and brand names on props.  This rule also applies to animated product, where the text was intentionally created, but theoretically shot by the virtual camera.2.1.4 Titles & CreditsIf Programs are supplied in a language other than English, the Main Program Titles, inserts where appropriate, and End Credits should all be supplied in the local language (e.g. French, Italian, Chinese, etc.).  2.2 PROGRAM REQUIRMENTSPrograms should be delivered in a continuous form. It shall be free from any bumpers or commercial blacks.The first 30 seconds of a Program must be free of supers or matte material in the upper left or upper right corners of both the screen area (beginning at 4x3 safe,) to allow for Program rating and closed captioning bug insertions.  Also, do not place text in the lower left and right corners of picture (beginning at 4x3 safe) for the first 30 seconds of the Program.  This space is used for logos, show titles, etc.  In addition, the lower-left corner must always be free of critical action (such as characters speaking) so as to allow for the network logo.2.2.1 Aspect Ratio & Safe AreasAll Programs are to be shot and mastered with the aspect ratio of 16x9, otherwise expressed as 1:78:1. Full Frame with no letterboxing and no use of pan and scan.  Concurrently, all 16x9 Programs must be center-cut extractable to the 4x3 aspect ratio, without the need for pan and scan or repositioning of shots or as 16x9 anamorphic with proper header tags for accurate playback. All text, including main titles and end credits must fall within the 4x3 title-safe area.While composing each shot, every effort must be made to keep all main subjects and action within the 4x3 area of the 16x9 frame.  The entire 16x9 picture area must be free of all non-story elements such as lighting equipment, camera hoods, microphone booms, etc.2.2.2 Post Assembly RequirementsIn order to ensure the integrity of multiple down-converted formats, a high level of digital resolution must be maintained throughout the post assembly process. Programs must be captured at 10-bit color depth and on-lined uncompressed or with a lossless compression scheme.  Any deviations from this requirement will require prior approval from BVI.Particularly for Programs in HD, mixed frame rates within programs are not permitted. Vari-speeding, editing between frames, and any other practices that corrupt the 23.98/25 segmented-frame sequence are not permitted.  Any graphics or effects added or layered to the HD material during post assembly must match the 23.98/25 segmented-frame sequence perfectly and must be of equal or higher resolution.2.2.3 PSE (Photo-Sensitive Epilepsy) SafetyAll Programs must conform to the PSE safety guidelines as outlined in Appendix 1 of ITU-R BT.1702 Ã¢ÂÂGuidance for the reduction of photosensitive epileptic seizures caused by televisionÃ¢ÂÂ.  This is to ensure the safety of viewers that may be susceptible to epileptic seizures brought on by certain visual stimuli such as bright flashes and various line patterns.All originally produced Programs are subject to testing by BVI for PSE safety, through the Harding Flash and Pattern Analyzer.  Any Program that fails the Harding analyzer must be modified so as to render a passed Harding test report.  BVI may make modifications to supplied Program to bring failed Program up to safe PSE standards.  To identify problematic sequences early in the animation or production process, it is highly encouraged that Producers submit suspect scenes to their relevant BVI contact as soon as available.  Such material should be submitted as a file or tape in accordance to the respective delivery specifications below.For more information on PSE safety and the Harding Flash and Pattern Analyzer, please visit the Harding website at http://www.hardingfpa.com/resources/broadcast-guidelines/2.2.4 Telephone Numbers & License PlatesAny telephone numbers or auto license plate numbers that appear legibly on screen must be cleared for air.  On-screen numbers must either be cleared legally or have a lesser amount of digits than would be required to successfully dial that number from anywhere.Ã¢ÂÂ2.2.5 Audio Stem GuidelinesMusic and Effects (M&E) Mixing M&E tracks are to be created in stereo and should cover all of the music and effects as heard in the original composite mix, with the exception of laugh tracks and human vocalizations (see below). They should match in quality of sound and perspective. Foreign dialogue, narration, announcers, whether spoken by a main or ancillary character must be included as a separate audio stem in the optional tracks (and kept off the M&E stems).   Crowd Walla All crowd walla and background conversation containing discernible English/Original Language must be replaced with Ã¢ÂÂneutral wallaÃ¢ÂÂ (walla in which English/ Original Language words cannot be heard) in the M&E. Police radios, TV and radio broadcasts, etc. that have discernible English/ Original Language must be removed from the M&E. These effects can be augmented with a generic, non-discernible version.  Music or effects that occur on a TV or radio program within the show should remain in the M&E. If music vocals are story point, they should also be removed and replaced by an instrumental music version.Human VocalizationsAll vocalizations (sighs, coughs, grunts, burps, etc.) performed by actors with speaking roles or featured non-speaking roles should be kept OFF the M&E track. Human vocalizations that are taken from licensed effects libraries should be included on the M&E track. Likewise, simulated vocalizations that are electronically produced should also be included on the M&E track.Music VocalsThis includes any Karaoke performances, either on-camera, or off. Be aware that any song performed on-camera will almost always require an accompanying instrumental-only version as a separate stem.  Note: This may require a second, non-vocal performance of the song to be recorded on-set or by the showÃ¢ÂÂs composer. As a general rule, all celebrity and non-story point background (or ambiance) vocals can remain in the M&E. However, any songs must also be supplied with an accompanying instrumental-only version as a separate stem whenever possible.All songs that are narrative, story point or expository must place the instrumental version of the song in the M&E. Lead character vocals as well as main and end credit vocals should have instrumental only versions in the M&E.Practical EffectsPolice radios, TV and radio broadcasts, etc. that have discernible English/Original Language in the composite track must be removed from the M&E. These effects can be augmented with a generic, non-discernible version.  Music or effects (only) that occur on a TV or radio program within the show should remain in the M&E.  Ambience & Room ToneBackground ambiance must be identical to that available on the original production dialogue track. Air fill, presence, outdoor tone or appropriate room tone should run throughout the dubbed program to compensate for this Ã¢ÂÂdead air.Ã¢ÂÂ This should be a natural sound, and not resemble tape hiss. The appropriate backgrounds present in the original composite mix are also required. Backgrounds such as TV or radio shows, music or traffic should change perspective if a door opens or closes or if the action moves to another location. For example, interior and exterior car presence should be reproduced accurately.Foreign LanguageAll foreign language spoken in the original domestic version is usually not included in the M&E, but should be provided on a separate audio track of file.  There are situations however when a speaking character never speaks using original version language and the location of that language is established in the context of the story, or the use of that language is appropriate for the scene.  In these cases the foreign language may exist on the M&E.EffectsAll on-screen moving effects (footsteps, traffic, etc.) that are present within the original version must be covered or duplicated as realistically as possible in the foreign M&E. Noises such as eating, biting, slurping, kissing bubble-gum pops, whistling, snoring should be in the M&E, if and only if they are in accordance to the instruction found above under Ã¢ÂÂHuman Vocalizations.Ã¢ÂÂ Any effect that is not an intonation of the actor should be included in the M&E.Any character that never speaks a known language but does make vocal effects such as animal noises, mimicking sound effects, or gibberish should be provided by the production company and included in the M&E , if and only if they are in accordance to the instruction found above under Ã¢ÂÂHuman VocalizationsÃ¢ÂÂ. Ã¢ÂÂ. If these vocalisations or effects are married to the original production dialogue, they are to be recreated and provided by the production company and match as closely as possible to the original performance.Foley Body movements and cloth should be covered. This includes, but is not limited to sit-downs, gesturing, arms down to sides, pats and slaps on the back (or other body parts), handshakes, etc. The texture of the cloth and the type furniture must be taken into consideration when augmenting any movement.Footsteps Unless there is a compelling story point or creative reason not to include them all, footsteps will be covered, both in the composite mix and the M&E. Footsteps should be foleyed, and not taken from an effects library. Perspective, weight of character walking, texture of surface, etc. must be matched as closely as possible. Dog paw clicks, horses, or other animal sounds should also be foleyed appropriately.Laugh TracksLaughs need to be delivered when applicable, such as with sitcoms. If present in the composite mix, a stereo laugh track must be built to match the composite mix, in terms of sync, quality and dimension.  The laugh tracks must be free of English/Original Language dialogue and augmented to match the composite mix.However, the built laugh tracks are NOT to be mixed into the M&E tracks, but are to be kept separate and supplied per the requirements detailed below in Section 2.6 Ã¢ÂÂAudio Master Delivery.Ã¢ÂÂ  2.2.6 Subtitling & CaptioningWhere such data is available, it shall be delivered as a separate file in PAC or FPC format.2.3 PROGRAM FILE DELIVERYIn addition to the requirements under this section 2.3, all materials delivered in files shall comply with the Program Requirements in Section 2.2.2.3.1 File Delivery in HDFile-based HD media shall be delivered in ProRes 422 HQ format. XDCAM-HD422 50Mbps is accepted only if ProRes file is not available.Video Encoding for HDFile-based HD video media for distribution shall be encoded using the Apple ProRes HQ encoder, with the preset described as Ã¢ÂÂApple ProRes 422 (HQ) 1920x1080 25p (or 23.98p as applicable) 48kHz,Ã¢ÂÂ and with the following specifications: Parameters	SettingsCompressor	Apple ProRes 422 (HQ) Frame Size	1920x1080 Field Mode	ProgressiveFrame Rate	25fps (or 23.98fps as applicable)Field Dominance	NonePixel Aspect Ratio	SquareColor Depth	Millions of Colors (24 bit)Data Rate	Unconstrained VBRVideo Quality	100%Audio Encoding for HDFile-based HD audio media for distribution shall be PCM encoded, using the following specifications: Parameters	SettingsAudio Rate	48 kHzSample Depth	16-bitNumber of Channels	24 (if available)The following track configuration will be used: Audio tracks	ContentCh. 1 & 2	English/Original language StereoCh. 3 & 4	M&E StereoCh. 5 & 6	English/Original language MonoCh. 7 & 8	M&E MonoCh. 9	Mono English/Original language (SOT)Ch. 10	Mono SFX (where available) Ch. 11 & 12	Stereo music (or Mono where available)Ch. 13 & 14	Stereo laugh track (or Mono when applicable)Ch. 15 to 24	Ancillary tracks (VO, foreign languages, etc.)Additional ancillary tracks (where available) i.e.: SOT, VO, SFX, Music, Mixed Mono, Foreign Languages etc need to be provided as separate files according to Section 2.4 Ã¢ÂÂAudio Master DeliveryÃ¢ÂÂ. 2.3.2 File Wrapper & Time CodeAll file-based media for distribution shall be wrapped using the Quicktime wrapper. Time code information must be included in the QuickTime wrapper. Both longitudinal time code (LTC) and vertical interval time code (VITC) must be recorded throughout the line-up and Program. Quicktime encoders will place primary time code information (such as LTC) or other, secondary time code information (such as VITC) consistently.File Naming Conventions All incoming Programs delivered in files shall conform to the following file naming convention:[Program title]_[Episode number]_v[Asset format]_a[Aspect Ratio]_l[Language]_r[Revision]For example, aaron stone_001_v1080p25_a16x9-178_lengIf the file is for a replacement, then the file shall be named as follows: aaron stone_001_v1080p25_a16x9-178_leng_r1Any deviation from these formats will not be accepted unless pre-approved by BVI.  2.4 AUDIO MASTER DELIVERYDigital files from Pro Tools are the required medium for the delivery of audio masters. Delivery of entire Pro Tools sessions is encouraged in the file delivery format described in Section 2.4.1 Ã¢ÂÂAudio Master File Delivery FormatÃ¢ÂÂ below. The preferred delivery method of these files is via Aspera Faspex. Your BVI contact can provide details for delivery to BVIÃ¢ÂÂs Enterprise Faspex server.  2.4.1 Audio Master File Delivery FormatThe following settings shall be used for the audio master delivery:Parameters	SettingsPro Tools Version	6.0 or higher (select Ã¢ÂÂenforce Mac/PC compatibilityÃ¢ÂÂ checkbox)Format	Broadcast WaveResolution	24 bit, 48kHzTimecode frame rate	25/23.98 fps to match video origination2.4.2 Stereo Audio Master Mix StemsAll tracks must be in perfect synchronization with the Program, and shall adhere to the audio specifications in Section 1.2.1 Ã¢ÂÂAudio for Stereo Audio MixesÃ¢ÂÂ and with the audio tracks configuration in Section 2.3.1 Ã¢ÂÂFile Delivery in HDÃ¢ÂÂAdditional ancillary tracks (where available) i.e.: SOT, VO, SFX, Music, Mixed Mono, Foreign Languages etc need to be provided as separate files according to Section 2.4.1 Ã¢ÂÂAudio Master File Delivery FormatÃ¢ÂÂ.In addition, the following mix stems are to be provided:Dialogue L			Effects LDialogue R			Effects R Atmos .L			Music L	Atmos R				Music RFoley L				Vocals L			Foley R				Vocals R			Laughs L*			Laughs R*Delivery of entire Pro Tools sessions is encouraged in the file delivery format described above.* Laughs need to be delivered when applicable, such as with sitcoms. Likewise, if ancillary tracks, such as foreign languages, announcers, voiceovers, vocal stems, instrumentals without vocals, intercoms, walkie-talkie, tv/radio, voices altered electronically for creative effect are used, they must be provided as additional mix stems and properly labeled.  2.5 PROMOS REQUIREMENTSMedia file containing a fully edited texted version and fully edited textless version (no supers) containing all audio tracks and final mixes (as stated below) on Disk, OMF file and QuickTime reference of the Promo with guide track audio, music and effects tracks for versioning and such other incidental materials as may be required in accordance with the technical specifications set out below.i.	Texted Version VIDEO:  include all graphics, supers and lower thirdsAUDIO: Chan 1 & 2: Stereo Mix, Chan 3 & 4: Mono Mix/Mono Mixii.	Textless VersionVIDEO: remove all graphics, supers and lower thirdsAUDIO: Chan 1: SOT, Chan 2: VO, Chan 3: SFX, Chan 4: Music2.6 QUALITY ASSESSMENT AND CONTROLThe supplied Program shall be viewed on receipt to verify its suitability for transmission.  BVI reserves the right to reject any supplied material which does not meet the above specifications or has faults which would affect the quality of transmission.If a video master or audio master is rejected by BVI because of technical defects, Licensor shall repair said master and replace it fully based on the BVIÃ¢ÂÂs recommendation. The repaired master shall be sent to the BVI within seven (7) business days of receipt. A hard copy of the original QC report must be included, with notations indicating the repair status of all rejected impairments.  That is to say, each impairment must have a notation beside it stating that it has been fixed, or an explanation as to why not.  If a rejected impairment is not to be fixed, BVI must be notified prior to re-delivery of the material.If the file is damaged or if there is a technical problem throughout the entire program, a full replacement is required (see delivery specs above) with the original QA report notating the repairs.  In the event of full program replacement, all affected masters must be replaced.2.7 TECHNICAL QUERIES	The following technical consultants from BVI are available to offer their expertise and assistance in complying with the above requirements:	Name: Tan Siew Geok	Email: siew.geok.tan@disney.com	Tel: +65 6507 3357	Name: Alan Leong	Email: alan.leong@disney.com 	Tel: +65 6507 3367
